text:
- [Jon] Hello, I'm Jon Schwenn,
a principal TAM at AWS.

And I have a quick tip
for Apple developers
connecting remotely to a Mac.

Teams of Apple developers
will have remote Mac systems
as a part of their development platform.

For example, I'm using
an EC2 Mac instance,

which is hosted on a Mac
mini in the AWS Ohio region.

Here's an example of what
it looks like in the rack.

AWS EC2 is a global elastic
cloud infrastructure
made possible by custom software
and silicon that we call the Nitro System.

AWS created nitro cards
that attach over Thunderbolt

to a Mac mini, extending
the power and security

of the EC2 control plane
to run Mac OS in the cloud.

Before we get started,
I've included a link

in the description
below to a video showing

how you can allocate an
EC2 Mac dedicated host
and then launch an instance on it.

First, I wanna show you
what it typically looks like

when I connect to an EC2
Mac instance using VNC.
You can see that it's easy to connect to
and it's responsive.

This is done over VNC, so
you'll want to route this
through an SSH tunnel for security.
I already have an ID loaded
and yeah, this is how it works.
But there are other options
for making remote desktop connections.

If your company already
has the Citrix desktop

as a service environment
for Windows or Linux host,

you can now use that
for macOS hosts as well.
So I've installed the Citrix client,
the VDA client on this Mac mini.
So I wanna show you what that looks like.

So I'll just go to click
over for my Mac desktop,
which is the exact same Mac mini.

You can see here that it's
starting the environment

with the progress thing
on the bottom corner.
So now this is the exact same Mac mini.

You will notice a
difference in the experience
and the additional screen resolution
allowing for easier management.

This connection is using the
HDX technology from Citrix

connecting initially over
a standard SSL report.

Additionally, we are
able to redirect audio
in and out, USB, webcam connections
between this machine

and the machine on my
desk that I'm working on.

All of this though, is
configurable to increase security

by the administrators of
your Citrix environment.
So that's it.
I hope this quick tip helps
and you check out the links below
to learn more about EC2 Mac
and the Citrix VDA options for macOS.
Thank you very much.
